science.headline: How Animals Build a Sense of Direction
science.teaser: Researchers recorded the neurons that shape directional navigation as bats explored a remote island off the coast of Tanzania. The post How Animals Build a Sense of Direction first appeared on Quanta Magazine
science.tldr: Undermines long-held theories on animal navigation and spatial awareness

science.headline: How Being a Good Dad Makes for Healthier Children
science.teaser: Paternal warmth before the age of 1 can set the tone for the family and influence physical health years later The post How Being a Good Dad Makes for Healthier Children appeared first on Nautilus .
science.tldr: Establishes a foundation for physical health through paternal warmth

science.headline: Heartworms Might Be Much More Ancient Than We Thought
science.teaser: Understanding their intricate past could be key to future treatments for pups The post Heartworms Might Be Much More Ancient Than We Thought appeared first on Nautilus .
science.tldr: Reveals the origins of heartworms, potentially leading to new treatments

science.headline: Construction of complex and diverse DNA sequences using DNA three-way junctions
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10006-0 Sidewinder enables high-fidelity DNA assembly by separating the information that guides assembly from the final assembled sequence.
science.tldr: Identifies a new method for assembling complex DNA sequences

science.headline: Temporal tissue dynamics from a spatial snapshot
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09876-1 One-shot tissue dynamics reconstruction can infer changes in tissue composition over time, from single-time-point spatial proteomics of human cancers.
science.tldr: Reconstructing tissue dynamics provides crucial insight into cellular behavior and evolution

science.headline: Detailed View of Solar Flare Birth Caught for the First Time
science.teaser: They start small and end huge The post Detailed View of Solar Flare Birth Caught for the First Time appeared first on Nautilus .
science.tldr: Captures the first detailed view of solar flare birth in history

science.headline: Rock art from at least 67,800 years ago in Sulawesi
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09968-y A hand stencil painted on a cave wall on a small island off the coast of Sulawesi more than 67,800 years ago suggests a very early occupation of Wallacea.
science.tldr: Recognizes oldest known human artistic expression outside Africa

science.headline: Core–envelope miscibility in sub-Neptunes and super-Earths
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09970-4 First-principles molecular dynamics driven by density functional theory is used to show that silicate and hydrogen are completely miscible over a wide range of plausible core–envelope pressure–temperature conditions.
science.tldr: Reveals key details about composition and stability of sub-Neptunes planets

science.headline: Symmetry, microscopy and spectroscopy signatures of altermagnetism
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09883-2 The symmetry, microscopy and spectroscopy signatures of altermagnetism are reviewed, and compared with traditional ferromagnetism and Néel antiferromagnetism, and magnetic phases with symmetry-protected compensated non-colline
science.tldr: Reveals unexpected properties of altermagnetism through novel symmetry observations

science.headline: Pyramidal neurons proportionately alter cortical interneuron subtypes
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09996-8 Pyramidal neuron-driven mechanisms actively promote the survival and terminal differentiation of their associated interneuron subtypes.
science.tldr: Promotes new understanding of cortical circuitry and neuronal interactions

science.headline: Afar fossil shows broad distribution and versatility of Paranthropus
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09826-x With its attribution to Paranthropus, a 2.6-million-year-old partial mandible expands the range of the genus into the Afar region of Ethiopia and adds to our understanding of hominin evolution in eastern Africa.
science.tldr: Unveils new information about Paranthropus with Afar fossil discovery

science.headline: Extreme barocaloric effect at dissolution
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10013-1 An extreme barocaloric effect in NH4SCN aqueous solutions is enabled by pressure-induced dissolution and precipitation, but without using a separate heat-transfer liquid.
science.tldr: Reveals a new mechanism for barocaloric effects in aqueous solutions

science.headline: Four camera-type eyes in the earliest vertebrates from the Cambrian Period
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09966-0 Early vertebrates, particularly myllokunmingids, possessed four camera-type eyes (a pair of lateral eyes and pineal and parapineal organs), which indicates that these structures functioned in image formation, in support of the
science.tldr: Reveals a new understanding of early vertebrate vision and sensory capabilities

philosophy.headline: Stevenson’s Treasure
philosophy.teaser: Robert Louis Stevenson (1850–94) belongs at the head of a select company of writers renowned in their day who are no longer taken seriously, or for that matter read much, by most adults... The post Stevenson’s Treasure appeared first on First Things .
philosophy.tldr: Revises our understanding by shedding light on Stevenson's literary legacy

philosophy.headline: Fact-Checking the New Yorker
philosophy.teaser: Back in the day, when the New Yorker set the standard for literary elegance among serious American journals, writers were driven to distraction by the fanatical fact-checking characteristic of... The post Fact-Checking the New Yorker appeared first on First Things .
philosophy.tldr: Challenges the notion that The New Yorker remains the standard for literary elegance

philosophy.headline: Looking Down the Tree (Review)
philosophy.teaser: by Paul Braterman Looking Down the Tree, The Evolutionary Biology of Human Origins, Mitchell B. Cruzan, Oxford University Press, 2025 This book has an ambitious and praiseworthy agenda, to discuss a wide range of specifically human characteristics, in the context of the selection pressures operating
philosophy.tldr: Reveals new perspectives on human origins through evolutionary biology

philosophy.headline: Philosophy Professors Among Recent NEH Grant Winners
philosophy.teaser: The National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH) has announced the winners of its latest round of grants, and several philosophy professors are among them. . They and their projects are: David Ebrey (University of Barcelona) Plato’s Inferences about the Soul Research and writing leading to a book on
philosophy.tldr: Recognizes the value of humanities research in academia and society

philosophy.headline: Bas van Fraassen Wins Schock Prize
philosophy.teaser: Bastiaan “Bas” van Fraassen, professor emeritus of philosophy at Princeton University, has been awarded the 2026 Rolf Schock Prize in Logic and Philosophy. The Schock Prize in Logic and Philosophy is bestowed by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences (KVA). Winners each receive 600,000 Swedish kronor
philosophy.tldr: Awarding Bas van Fraassen recognizes his significant contributions

philosophy.headline: Thrill-Seeking and the Break Point in Point Break
philosophy.teaser: by Tim Sommers “Happiness is that which all things aim at” according to Aristotle. All virtues – arete (ἀρετή) or “excellences” – are the mean between two extremes. We should choose courage over cowardice, sure, but also over being too bold. Stick to the tame middle. Epicureans and Stoics counsel ag
philosophy.tldr: Examines why Aristotle's concept of mean virtues matters in thrill-seeking

society.headline: The Best Books of 2025
society.teaser: The New Yorker’s editors and critics choose this year’s essential reads in fiction, poetry, and nonfiction.
society.tldr: Highlights essential reads for readers seeking meaningful literary and intellectual experiences

society.headline: The Power of Grievance
society.teaser: What history reveals about authoritarianism’s animating force.
society.tldr: Uncovering history's role in authoritarianism's rise is crucial for understanding its power

society.headline: Why Trump Sides With Putin
society.teaser: Fiona Hill on Putin’s long game, Trump’s transactional foreign policy, and the danger of mistaking size and bluster for real power. Plus: Trump’s grocery-price fiction and V. S. Naipaul’s Among the Believers .
society.tldr: Challenges US foreign policy with Russia's long-term strategic interests

society.headline: South Korea Can Stand Up to China
society.teaser: With its allies, Seoul has enough leverage to push back.
society.tldr: Challenges China's growing influence in East Asia are crucial for Korea

society.headline: If You Read This You Are Gay
society.teaser: For the terminally online, politics à la carte.
society.tldr: Highlights existing social norms and expectations around sexuality

society.headline: How Europe Can Respond to Trump’s Greenland Imperialism
society.teaser: The President’s obsession with acquiring the Danish territory has put the transatlantic alliance at risk.
society.tldr: Challenges the transatlantic alliance with potential irreversible consequences

society.headline: The Battle for One of the Richest and Smallest Counties in Texas
society.teaser: A few families have been duelling for control of Loving County for decades. Then the followers of a hustle-culture influencer moved in.
society.tldr: Challenges the control and future of Loving County's small government structure

society.headline: Catholicism Has Declined in Latin America Over the Past Decade
society.teaser: Growing numbers of Latin Americans are religiously unaffiliated, but belief in God remains high across the region. The post Catholicism Has Declined in Latin America Over the Past Decade appeared first on Pew Research Center .
society.tldr: Declines in Catholicism reveal shifts in Latin American spiritual identity

society.headline: 2. Religious and spiritual beliefs in Latin America
society.teaser: Majorities in the six countries surveyed believe in God, in life after death, and that spells, curses or other magic can influence people’s lives. The post 2. Religious and spiritual beliefs in Latin America appeared first on Pew Research Center .
society.tldr: Undermines traditional notions of science and secularism in Latin America

society.headline: A Début Novel About the Quest for Eternal Youth
society.teaser: In Madeline Cash’s “Lost Lambs,” the distinction between responsible adult and dependent child has frayed.
society.tldr: Raises questions about adult responsibility and dependency in contemporary society

society.headline: Memory’s Role in Chile’s Democratic Rebirth
society.teaser: In post-Pinochet Chile, public memory became a pathway to accountability. The post Memory’s Role in Chile’s Democratic Rebirth appeared first on JSTOR Daily .
society.tldr: Unravels decades-old narratives to hold perpetrators accountable

society.headline: 1. Religious affiliation in Latin America
society.teaser: Catholics remain the largest religious group in Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru, while second-largest groups vary. The post 1. Religious affiliation in Latin America appeared first on Pew Research Center .
society.tldr: Upsets long-held assumptions about regional religious demographics significantly

society.headline: Trump Wants to Be the New Polk
society.teaser: His interest in the 11th president’s legacy has conjured up the specter of manifest destiny.
society.tldr: Disputes Trump's historical legacy with that of 11th President Polk

society.headline: Bringing Zohran Mamdani to the Big Screen
society.teaser: In 2023, Julia Bacha began filming a backbench state assemblyman. Little did she know that she was making a documentary about the next mayor of New York City.
society.tldr: Films about politicians bring transparency and scrutiny to public office

society.headline: Why Albums Drop and Movies Launch
society.teaser: The ephemeral nature of contemporary music consumption has made it much harder to elevate an album—even a very good one—into the category of an event.
society.tldr: Overturns a century of music's event-driven business model and cultural significance

books.headline: B-Sides: Lydia Millet’s “Oh Pure and Radiant Heart”
books.teaser: What if you wanted something a bit more from the giants of the past: to force them to look at what they’ve done, to hold them accountable for the world we now inhabit, thanks to them? The post B-Sides: Lydia Millet’s “Oh Pure and Radiant Heart” appeared first on Public Books .
books.tldr: Forces giants of the past to confront their historical harm

essays.headline: Kamilah Aisha Moon, Salman Rushdie, and an Archive of Love
essays.teaser: Towards the end of The Flower Bearers, we see Rachel Eliza Griffiths visit the papers of Lucille Clifton and Alice Walker at Emory University and the papers of Toni Cade Bambara and Audre Lorde at Spelman College. We see her hands shake over Clifton’s spirit writing, carefully lift the first draft o
essays.tldr: Discovers significance in Rachel Eliza Griffiths' visit to authors' papers collection

essays.headline: A Genius Can Always Get Their Hands on a Violin
essays.teaser: Prodigies Mom is a groupie, so when Dad has a gig, no matter how big or small, she forces us to go as a family. She’s too dressed up: wearing tights with seams up the back, a low-cut dress and heels that will ensure eyes follow us into every room. I do the opposite: I […] The post A Genius Can Alway
essays.tldr: Disappointingly, it highlights family dynamics overshadowed by parental enthusiasm
